{{Internet}} Instead of a single "inventor", the [[Internet]] was developed by many people over many years. The following are some '''Internet pioneers''' who contributed to its early development. These include early theoretical foundations, specifying original protocols, and expansion beyond a research tool to wide deployment.
{{TOC right}}
==The pioneers==
===Claude Shannon=== {{main|Claude Shannon}} '''Claude Shannon''' (1916–2001) called the "father of modern [[information theory]]", published "[[A Mathematical Theory of Communication]]" in 1948. His paper gave a formal way of studying [[communication channel]]s. It established fundamental limits on the efficiency of communication over [[noisy channel]]s, and presented the challenge of finding families of codes to achieve capacity.<ref>[http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2001/shannon.html MIT "Professor Claude Shannon dies; was founder of digital communications"], MIT - News office, Cambridge, Massachusetts, February 27, 2001</ref>
===Vannevar Bush=== {{main|Vannevar Bush}} '''Vannevar Bush''' (1890–1974) helped to establish a partnership between U.S. military, university research, and independent think tanks. He was appointed Chairman of the [[National Defense Research Committee]] in 1940 by President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], appointed Director of the [[Office of Scientific Research and Development]] in 1941, and from 1946 to 1947, he served as chairman of the Joint Research and Development Board. Out of this would come [[DARPA]], which in turn would lead to the ARPANET Project.<ref name="iHist">{{cite web |title= Internet History |author= Bill Stewart |work= Living Internet web book |url= http://www.livinginternet.com/i/ii.htm |accessdate= March 30, 2011 }}</ref> His July 1945 [[The Atlantic Monthly|''Atlantic Monthly'']] article "[[As We May Think]]" proposed [[Memex]], a theoretical proto-[[hypertext]] computer system in which an individual compresses and stores all of their books, records, and communications, which is then mechanized so that it may be consulted with exceeding speed and flexibility.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bush|first=Vannevar|authorlink=Vannevar Bush|date=July 1945|title=As We May Think|journal=[[The Atlantic Monthly]]|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/194507/bush}}</ref>
===Paul Baran=== {{main|Paul Baran}} '''Paul Baran''' (1926–2011) developed the field of redundant distributed networks while conducting research at [[RAND Corporation]] starting in 1959 when Baran began investigating the development of survivable communication networks. This led to a series of papers titled "On Distributed communications"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rand.org/about/history/baran.list.html |title=About RAND | History and Mission | Paul Baran: Publications on Distributed Communications |publisher=Rand.org |date=2011-12-23 |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> that in 1964 described a detailed architecture for a distributed survivable packet switched communications network.<ref name="iHist"/> In 2012, Baran was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name=IHOF-2012>[http://www.internethalloffame.org/inductees/year/2012 2012 Inductees], [[Internet Hall of Fame]] website. Last accessed April 24, 2012</ref>
===J. C. R. Licklider=== [[File:J. C. R. Licklider.jpg |thumb|150px |J. C. R. Licklider]] {{main|J. C. R. Licklider}} '''Joseph Carl Robnett Licklider''' (1915–1990) was a faculty member of [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], and researcher at [[BBN Technologies|Bolt, Beranek and Newman]]. He developed the idea of a universal network at the [[Information Processing Techniques Office]] (IPTO) of the [[United States Department of Defense]] [[DARPA|Advanced Research Projects Agency]] (ARPA).<ref name="iHist"/><ref name="Columbia">{{cite web |url= http://www.columbia.edu/~jrh29/years.html |title= JCR Licklider (1915-1990) |author= Jay R. Hauben |publisher= Columbia University |accessdate= March 30, 2011 }}</ref> He headed IPTO from 1962 to 1963, and again from 1974 to 1975. His 1960 paper [[Man-Computer Symbiosis#J.C.R. Licklider: Man-Computer Symbiosis|"Man-Computer Symbiosis"]] envisions that mutually-interdependent, "living together", tightly-coupled human brains and computing machines would prove to complement each other's strengths.<ref>[http://medg.lcs.mit.edu/people/psz/Licklider.html "Man-Computer Symbiosis"], J.C.R. Licklider, ''IRE Transactions on Human Factors in Electronics'', vol. HFE-1, pp.4-11, Mar 1960</ref>
===Donald Davies=== {{main|Donald Davies}} '''Donald Davies''' (1924–2000) independently invented and named the concept of [[packet switching]] in 1965 at the United Kingdom's [[National Physical Laboratory (United Kingdom)|National Physical Laboratory]] (NPL).<ref name=Isaacson2014>{{cite book|last1=Isaacson|first1=Walter|title=The Innovators: How a Group of Hackers, Geniuses, and Geeks Created the Digital Revolution|date=2014|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=9781476708690|page=237|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4V9koAEACAAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA237#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> In the same year, he proposed a national data network based on packet switching in the UK. After the proposal was not taken up nationally, during 1966 he headed a team which produced a design for a local area network to serve the needs of NPL and prove the feasibility of packet switching. In 1967, a written version of the proposal entitled ''NPL Data Network'' was presented by a member of his team (Roger Scantlebury) at the [[Association for Computing Machinery|ACM]] conference in [[Gatlinburg]]. The paper described how equipment (''[[node (networking)|nodes]]'') used to transmit [[Signal (electrical engineering)|signals]] (''[[Network packet|packets]]'') would be connected by electrical links to re-transmit the signals between and to the nodes, and [[Interface (computing)|interface]] computers would be used to link node networks to so-called [[time-sharing]] computers and other [[User (computing)|users]]. The interface computers would transmit [[Multiplexing|multiplex]] signals between networks, and nodes would [[switch]] transmissions while connected to electrical circuitry functioning at a rate of processing amounting to mega-bits.<ref name=Hempstead2005/> Scantlebury suggested packet switching for use in the ARPANET; [[Lawrence Roberts (scientist)|Larry Roberts]] incorporated it into the design and sought input from Paul Baran as well.<ref name=Gillies2000>{{cite book|last1=Gillies|first1=James|last2=Cailliau|first2=Robert|title=How the Web was Born: The Story of the World Wide Web|date=2000|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0192862073|page=25|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pIH-JijUNS0C&lpg=PA25&ots=MKZj0F7pJN&pg=PA25#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref><ref name=Abbate2000>{{cite book|last1=Abbate|first1=Jane|title=Inventing the Internet|date=2000|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=0262261332|pages=37-8|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9BfZxFZpElwC&lpg=PA37&ots=TLlYUwwakj&pg=PA37#v=onepage&q&f=false|quote=Although he was aware of the concept of packet switching, Roberts was not sure how to implement it in a large network.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Scantlebury|first=Roger|title=''Internet pioneers airbrushed from history''|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/jun/25/internet-pioneers-airbrushed-from-history|date=25 June 2013|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=1 August 2015}}</ref> Davies gave the first public demonstration of packet switching in 1968 and built the local area [[NPL network]] in England, influencing other research in the UK and Europe.<ref>{{cite news|title=The accelerator of the modern age|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/7541123.stm|work=BBC News|accessdate=19 May 2009 | date=5 August 2008}}</ref> The NPL network followed by ARPANET were the first two networks in the world to use packet switching.<ref name=Hempstead2005>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2ZCNAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA574&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false|author1=C. Hempstead |author2=W. Worthington |title=Encyclopedia of 20th-Century Technology|publisher=[[Routledge]]|date=2005}}</ref> In 2012, Davies was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Charles M. Herzfeld=== {{main |Charles M. Herzfeld}} '''Charles M. Herzfeld''' (1925-2017) was an American scientist and scientific manager, best known for his time as Director of DARPA, during which, among other things, he personally took the decision to authorize the creation of the ARPANET, the predecessor of the Internet.
In 2012, Herzfeld was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Bob Taylor=== {{main|Robert Taylor (computer scientist)}} '''Robert W. Taylor''' (February 10, 1932 – April 13, 2017) was director of [[DARPA|ARPA]]'s [[Information Processing Techniques Office]] from 1965 through 1969, where he convinced ARPA to fund a computer network.<ref>{{cite news |title= Robert Taylor, Innovator Who Shaped Modern Computing, Dies at 85 |author= John Markoff |work= New York Times |date= April 13, 2017 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/14/technology/robert-taylor-innovator-who-shaped-modern-computing-dies-at-85.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=second-column-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news }}</ref> From 1970 to 1983, he managed the Computer Science Laboratory of the [[PARC (company)|Xerox Palo Alto Research Center]] (PARC), where technologies such as [[Ethernet]] and the [[Xerox Alto]] were developed.<ref>{{cite news |title= Building the Internet: Bob Taylor won the National Medal of Technology "For visionary leadership in the development of modern computing technology" |date= October 11, 2000 |author= Marion Softky |work= The California Almanac |url= http://www.almanacnews.com/morgue/2000/2000_10_11.taylor.html |accessdate= March 30, 2011 }}</ref> He was the founder and manager of [[Digital Equipment Corporation]]'s [[DEC Systems Research Center|Systems Research Center]] until 1996.<ref>{{cite book |title= A Brief History of the Future: Origins of the Internet |author= John Naughton |date= October 5, 2000 |publisher= Phoenix |isbn= 978-0-7538-1093-4 }}</ref> The 1968 paper, "The Computer as a Communication Device", that he wrote together with [[J.C.R. Licklider]] starts out: "In a few years, men will be able to communicate more effectively through a machine than face to face."<ref name="com68">{{cite journal |title= The Computer as a Communication Device |author1= J.C.R. Licklider |author2= Robert Taylor |work= Science and Technology |date= April 1968 |url= http://www.kurzweilai.net/the-computer-as-a-communication-device |authorlink1= J.C.R. Licklider }}</ref> And while their vision would take more than "a few years", the paper lays out the future of what the Internet would eventually become.
===Larry Roberts=== {{main|Lawrence Roberts (scientist)}} '''Lawrence G. "Larry" Roberts''' (born 1937) is an [[United States|American]] [[computer scientist]].<ref name="NAE_2001">{{cite web|url=http://www.nae.edu/Activities/Projects20676/Awards/20681/PastWinners/page2001.aspx|publisher=[[National Academy of Engineering]]|year=2001|title=2001 Draper Prize Recipients' Bios}}</ref> After earning his [[PhD]] in [[electrical engineering]] from [[MIT]] in 1963, Roberts continued to work at MIT's [[Lincoln Laboratory]] where in 1965 he connected Lincoln Lab's [[TX-2]] computer to the [[System Development Corporation|SDC]] [[AN/FSQ-32|Q-32]] computer in [[Santa Monica]].<ref name="Wired_2001_05">{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/9.05/caspian.html?pg=3&topic=&topic_set=|title=The n -Dimensional Superswitch|date=May 2001|author=Josh McHugh|publisher=[[Wired Magazine]]}}</ref> In 1966, he became a program manager in the [[DARPA|ARPA]] [[Information Processing Techniques Office]] (IPTO), where he led the development of the [[ARPANET]], the first wide area [[packet switching]] network. Roberts applied [[Donald Davies]]' concepts of packet switching for the ARPANET, and also sought input from [[Paul Baran]] and [[Leonard Kleinrock]].<ref name=Gillies2000/><ref name=Isaacson2014>{{cite book|last1=Isaacson|first1=Walter|title=The Innovators: How a Group of Hackers, Geniuses, and Geeks Created the Digital Revolution|date=2014|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=9781476708690|page=237|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4V9koAEACAAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA237#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref><ref name=Abbate2000/> After Robert Taylor left ARPA in 1969, Roberts became director of the IPTO. In 1973, he left ARPA to commercialize the nascent technology in the form of [[Telenet]], the first data network utility, and served as its [[CEO]] from 1973 to 1980.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/04_39/b3901030_mz072.htm|publisher=[[Business Week]]|title=Larry Roberts:He made the Net Work|date=2004-09-27|author=Otis Port}}</ref> In 2012, Roberts was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Leonard Kleinrock=== {{main|Leonard Kleinrock}} '''Leonard Kleinrock''' (born 1934) published his first paper on [[queueing theory]] in digital networks, "Information Flow in Large Communication Nets", in 1961. After completing his Ph.D. thesis in 1962, which provided a fundamental theory of digital [[message switching]], he moved to [[UCLA]]. In the late 1960s, building on his earlier work on queueing theory, Kleinrock carried out theoretical work to model the performance of packet-switched networks, which underpinned the development of the ARPANET.<ref name=Gillies2000/><ref name=Hempstead2005/><ref name=Isaacson2014/> In 1969, a team at UCLA connected a computer to an [[Interface Message Processor]], becoming the first node on ARPANET.<ref>{{cite web |title= Leonard Kleinrock's Personal History/Biography: The Birth of the Internet |date= August 27, 1996 |author= Leonard Kleinrock |url= http://www.isoc.org/awards/postel/memory.shtml |accessdate= March 30, 2011 }}</ref> His theoretical work on [[hierarchical routing]] in the late 1970s with student [[Farouk Kamoun]] remains critical to the operation of the Internet today. In 2012, Kleinrock was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Douglas Engelbart=== [[File:Douglas Engelbart in 2008.jpg |thumb|150px |Douglas Engelbart]] {{main|Douglas Engelbart}} '''Douglas Engelbart''' (1925-2013) was an early researcher at the [[SRI International|Stanford Research Institute]]. His [[Augmentation Research Center]] laboratory became the second node on the ARPANET in October 1969, and SRI became the early Network Information Center, which evolved into the [[domain name registry]].<ref name="isoc">{{cite web |title= A Brief History of the Internet |author1=Barry M. Leiner |author2=Vinton G. Cerf |author3=David D. Clark |author4=Robert E. Kahn |author5=Leonard Kleinrock |author6=Daniel C. Lynch |author7=Jon Postel |author8=Larry G. Roberts |author9=Stephen Wolff |publisher= Internet Society |url= http://www.isoc.org/internet/history/brief.shtml |accessdate= March 30, 2011 }}</ref>
Engelbart was a committed, vocal proponent of the development and use of computers and [[computer network]]s to help cope with the world’s increasingly urgent and complex problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dougengelbart.org/colloquium/colloquium.html|title=The Unfinished Revolution II: Strategy and Means for Coping with Complex Problems|work=Colloquium at Stanford University|publisher=[[The Doug Engelbart Institute]]|date=April 2000|accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> He is best known for his work on the challenges of [[human–computer interaction]], resulting in the invention of the [[Mouse (computing)|computer mouse]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/sci/tech/newsid_1633000/1633972.stm|title=Mouse inventor strives for more|first=Alfred|last=Hermida|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=2001-11-05|accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> and the development of [[hypertext]], networked computers, and precursors to [[graphical user interface]]s.<ref name="acm">{{ACMPortal|id=81100342853}}</ref>
===Elizabeth Feinler=== [[File:ElizabethFeinler-2011.jpg |thumb|150px |Jake Feinler]] {{main|Elizabeth J. Feinler}} '''Elizabeth J. "Jake" Feinler''' (born 1931) was a staff member of [[Doug Engelbart|Doug Engelbart's]] [[Augmentation Research Center]] at [[SRI International|SRI]] and [[Principal investigator|PI]] for the [[InterNIC|Network Information Center]] (NIC) for the [[ARPANET]] and the [[Defense Data Network]] (DDN) from 1972 until 1989.<ref>[http://archive.computerhistory.org/resources/access/text/Oral_History/102702199.05.01.acc.pdf ''Oral History of Elizabeth (Jake) Feinler''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811175249/http://archive.computerhistory.org/resources/access/text/Oral_History/102702199.05.01.acc.pdf |date=2011-08-11 }}, Interviewed by Marc Weber, September 10, 2009, Reference no: X5378.2009, Computer History Museum, 49 pp.</ref><ref name=FeinlerSRIBio>{{cite web|url=http://www.sri.com/about/alumni/alumni-hall-fame-2000#Feinler|title=Alumni Hall of Fame: Elizabeth J. Feinler|publisher=[[SRI International]]|accessdate=2013-06-13}}</ref> In 2012, Feinler was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Louis Pouzin=== {{main|Louis Pouzin}} '''Louis Pouzin''' (born 1931) is a [[France|French]] [[computer scientist]]. He invented the [[datagram]] and designed an early packet communications network, [[CYCLADES]].<ref>[http://www.acm.org/sigs/sigcomm/sigcomm99/pouzin.html "Biography of Louis Pouzin, 1999 SIGCOMM Award Winner"], ACM SIGCOMM web site</ref> Concepts from his work were used by [[Bob Kahn|Robert Kahn]], [[Vinton Cerf]], and others in the development of [[TCP/IP]]. In 1997, Pouzin received the ACM [[SIGCOMM Award]] for "pioneering work on connectionless packet communication".<ref name=SIGCOM-1997>[http://www.sigcomm.org/awards/sigcomm-awards/postel-and-pouzin-award-details "Postel and Pouzin: 1997 SIGCOMM Award Winners"], ACM SIGCOMM web site</ref> Louis Pouzin was named a [[Chevalier of the Legion of Honor]] by the French government on March 19, 2003. In 2012, Pouzin was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Glenda Schroeder=== {{Content |Should Glenda Schroder be listed as an Internet pioneer?|date=March 2018}} {{main|Glenda Schroeder}} '''Glenda Schroeder''' is an American [[software engineer]] who described the first [[e-mail]] implementation <ref>[http://www.multicians.org/thvv/mail-history.html The History of Electronic Mail]</ref> in 1964-65 with [[Pat Crisman]] and [[Louis Pouzin]] by outlining a system of notifying users about backups of files.<ref>http://www.multicians.org/thvv/psn-39.pdf</ref> She is also noted for implementing the first [[command line]] [[user interface]] [[Shell (computing)|shell]]. This creation for the [[Multics]] operating system at [[MIT]] was the predecessor to the [[Unix shell]] implemented at [[Bell Labs]] and still in use today.<ref>[http://www.multicians.org/shell.html The Origin of the Shell<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===John Klensin=== {{Main |John Klensin}} '''John Klensin''''s involvement with Internet began in 1969, when he worked on the [[File Transfer Protocol]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.isoc.org/isoc/media/releases/980403pr.shtml |title=Internet Experts selected to fill top organizational posts |date=1998-04-03 |publisher=[[Internet Society|ISOC]] |accessdate=2011-07-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813055217/http://www.isoc.org/isoc/media/releases/980403pr.shtml |archivedate=2011-08-13 |df= }}</ref> Klensin was involved in the early procedural and definitional work for DNS administration and top-level domain definitions and was part of the committee that worked out the transition of DNS-related responsibilities between USC-ISI and what became ICANN.<ref>[http://www.internethalloffame.org/inductees/john-klensin "John Klensin biographical sketch"], Internet Hall of Fame, Internet Society, 2012</ref>
His career includes 30 years as a principal research scientist at [[MIT]], a stint as INFOODS Project Coordinator for the [[United Nations University]], Distinguished Engineering Fellow at [[MCI WorldCom]], and Internet Architecture Vice President at [[AT&T]]; he is now an independent consultant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icann.org/biog/klensin.htm|title=Biography of John Klensin at the ICANN web site|accessdate=2008-06-17}}</ref> In 1992 Randy Bush and John Klensin created the ''Network Startup Resource Center'',<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.nsrc.org/about.html#support |title = About the Network Startup Resource Center |work = [http://www.nsrc.org/ NSRC] |year = 1992 |accessdate = 2011-07-25 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110813094354/http://nsrc.org/about.html#support |archivedate = 2011-08-13 |df = }}</ref> helping dozens of countries to establish connections with [[FidoNet]], [[UseNet]], and when possible the [[Internet]].
In 2003, he received an [[International Committee for Information Technology Standards|International Committee for Information Technology Standards Merit Award]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.incits.org/Awards/honor.htm |title=INCITS Awards Honor Roll |publisher=[[International Committee for Information Technology Standards|INCITS]] |accessdate=2011-07-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801094436/http://www.incits.org/Awards/honor.htm |archivedate=2013-08-01 |df= }}</ref> In 2007, he was inducted as a Fellow of the [[Association for Computing Machinery]] for contributions to networking standards and Internet applications.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fellows.acm.org/fellow_citation.cfm?id=1101344&srt=alpha&alpha=K|title=List of 2007 ACM Fellows inductees|accessdate=2008-06-17}}</ref> In 2012, Klensin was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Bob Kahn=== [[File:Bob Kahn.jpg |thumb|150px |Bob Kahn]] {{main|Bob Kahn}} '''Robert E. "Bob" Kahn''' (born 1938) is an [[United States|American]] [[engineer]] and [[computer scientist]], who in 1974, along with [[Vinton G. Cerf|Vint Cerf]], invented the [[TCP/IP]] protocols.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://awards.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=4598637&srt=all&aw=140&ao=AMTURING&yr=2004 | title=Robert E Kahn | work=A. M. Turing Award | publisher=ACM | year=2004 | accessdate=2010-01-23 | quote=For pioneering work on internetworking, including the design and implementation of the Internet's basic communications protocols, TCP/IP, and for inspired leadership in networking. | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120703015809/http://amturing.acm.org/award_winners/kahn_4598637.cfm | archivedate=2012-07-03 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ieee.org/about/awards/medals/bell.html#sect3 |title=IEEE Alexander Graham Bell Medal |publisher=Ieee.org |date= |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> After earning a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] degree from [[Princeton University]] in 1964, he worked for [[AT&T Bell Laboratories]], as an [[assistant professor]] at [[MIT]], and at [[BBN Technologies|Bolt, Beranek and Newman]] (BBN), where he helped develop the [[ARPANET]] [[Interface Message Processor|IMP]]. In 1972, he began work at the [[Information Processing Techniques Office]] (IPTO) within [[DARPA|ARPA]]. In 1986 he left ARPA to found the [[Corporation for National Research Initiatives]] (CNRI), a nonprofit organization providing leadership and funding for research and development of the National Information Infrastructure<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnri.reston.va.us/directors_2.html|title=CNRI Officers and Directors|publisher=CNRI|accessdate=2009-02-25}}</ref>
===Vint Cerf=== [[File:Vint Cerf - 2010.jpg |thumb|150px |Vint Cerf, September 2010]] {{main|Vint Cerf}} '''Vinton G. "Vint" Cerf''' (born 1943) is an [[United States|American]] [[computer scientist]].<ref name="vita">[http://www.icann.org/correspondence/cerf-testimony-08feb01.htm#Vita Cerf's ''curriculum vitae'' as of February 2001], attached to a transcript of his testimony that month before the [[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Telecommunications and the Internet]], from [[ICANN]]'s website</ref> He is recognized as one of "[[People known as the father or mother of something#Technology|the fathers of the Internet]]",<ref>(see [http://www.gcn.com/print/25_2/38005-1.html?topic=interview Interview with Vinton Cerf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070609092123/http://www.gcn.com/print/25_2/38005-1.html?topic=interview |date=2007-06-09 }}, from a January 2006 article in ''Government Computer News''), Cerf is willing to call himself one of the Internet's fathers, citing [[Bob Kahn]] and [[Leonard Kleinrock]] in particular as being others with whom he should share that title.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Cerf | first1 = V. G. | title = The day the Internet age began | doi = 10.1038/4611202a | journal = Nature | volume = 461 | issue = 7268 | pages = 1202–1203 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19865146 | pmc = }}</ref> sharing this title with [[Bob Kahn]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://awards.acm.org/homepage.cfm?srt=all&awd=140 |title=ACM Turing Award, list of recipients |publisher=Awards.acm.org |accessdate=December 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212132624/http://awards.acm.org/homepage.cfm?awd=140&srt=all |archivedate=December 12, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ieee.org/about/awards/medals/bell.html#sect3 |title=IEEE Alexander Graham Bell Medal |publisher=Ieee.org |date=July 7, 2009 |accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref>
He earned his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] from [[UCLA]] in 1972. At UCLA he worked in Professor [[Leonard Kleinrock]]'s networking group that connected the first two nodes of the [[ARPANET]] and contributed to the ARPANET host-to-host protocol. Cerf was an [[Professor#Assistant professor|assistant professor]] at [[Stanford University]] from 1972–1976, where he conducted research on packet network interconnection protocols and co-designed the DoD [[TCP/IP]] protocol suite with [[Bob Kahn]]. He was a program manager for the [[DARPA|Advanced Research Projects Agency]] (ARPA) from 1976 to 1982. Cerf was instrumental in the formation of both the [[Internet Society]] and [[Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers]] (ICANN), serving as founding president of the Internet Society from 1992–1995 and in 1999 as Chairman of the Board and as ICANN Chairman from 2000 to 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icann.org/en/biog/cerf.htm |title=Vinton G. Cerf's biography at the Internet Society |publisher=Icann.org |date= |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> His many awards include the [[National Medal of Technology]],<ref name="vita"/> the [[Turing Award]],<ref name="turing">[https://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/16/technology/16internet.html?oref=login Cerf wins Turing Award] Feb 16, 2005</ref> the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]],<ref name="whitehouse">[https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2005/11/20051109-10.html 2005 Presidential Medal of Freedom recipients] from the White House website</ref> and membership in the [[National Academy of Engineering]] and the [[Internet Hall of Fame|Internet Society's Internet Hall of Fame]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
[[Image:SteveCrockerJI1.jpg|right|thumb |150px |Steve Crocker]]
===Peter Kirstein=== {{main|Peter T. Kirstein}} '''Peter T. Kirstein''' (born 1933) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[computer scientist]] and a leader in the international development of the Internet.<ref>[http://www.isoc.org/isoc/media/releases/030716pr.shtml "Peter T. Kirsten recognized with the Internet Society's Postel Award"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050906215856/http://www.isoc.org/isoc/media/releases/030716pr.shtml |date=2005-09-06 }}, July 16, 2003, Press Release, Internet Society</ref> In 1973, he established one of the first two international nodes of the ARPANET.<ref>[http://www.cs.ucl.ac.uk/staff/P.Kirstein/internationalactivity.html "Peter Kirstein's International Activities"], [[University College London]] web page</ref> In 1978 he co-authored "Issues in packet-network interconnection" with Vint Cerf, one of the early technical papers on the internet concept.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1109/PROC.1978.11147 | volume=66 | title=Issues in packet-network interconnection | year=1978 | journal=Proceedings of the IEEE | pages=1386–1408 | last1 = Cerf | first1 = V.G.}}</ref> His research group at [[University College London]] adopted [[TCP/IP]] in 1982, a year ahead of ARPANET, and played a significant role in the very earliest experimental Internet work.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Martin|first1=Olivier|title=The “Hidden” Prehistory of European Research Networking|date=2012|publisher=Trafford Publishing|isbn=1466938722|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=eTRYAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT17&lpg=PT17&source=bl&ots=UsJjMrqp-1&sig=tmFqs3B3Y6LDuMNmnc73z1_3f_E&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiqjJTC1b7WAhVJsBQKHQjcA94Q6AEISTAF#v=onepage&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Kirstein|first1=Peter T.|title=Early experiences with the ARPANET and Internet in the UK|url=http://nrg.cs.ucl.ac.uk/internet-history.html|publisher=Department of Computer Science, Systems and Networks Research Group, University College London|accessdate=13 April 2016}}</ref> Starting in 1983 he chaired the International Collaboration Board, which involved six NATO countries, served on the Networking Panel of the NATO Science Committee (serving as chair in 2001), and on Advisory Committees for the Australian Research Council, the Canadian Department of Communications, the German GMD, and the Indian Education and Research Network (ERNET) Project. He leads the Silk Project, which provides satellite-based Internet access to the [[Newly Independent States]] in the [[Southern Caucasus]] and [[Central Asia]]. In 2012, Kirstein was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Steve Crocker=== {{Main |Steve Crocker}} '''Steve Crocker''' (born 1944 in [[Pasadena, California]]) has worked in the [[ARPANET]] and [[Internet]] communities since their inception. As a UCLA graduate student in the 1960s, he helped create the ARPANET protocols which were the foundation for today's Internet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.magazine.ucla.edu/year1997/fall97_03.html|title=Wired!|author=Matthew Lyon|publisher=UCLA Magazine|date=Fall 1997}}</ref> He created the [[Request for Comments]] series,<ref>RFC 2468</ref> authoring the very first RFC and many more.<ref>RFC 1</ref> He was instrumental in creating the ARPA "Network Working Group", the forerunner of the modern [[Internet Engineering Task Force]].
Crocker has been a program manager at the [[Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency|Advanced Research Projects Agency]] (ARPA), a senior researcher at [[University of Southern California|USC]]'s [[Information Sciences Institute]], founder and director of the Computer Science Laboratory at [[The Aerospace Corporation]] and a vice president at [[Trusted Information Systems]]. In 1994, Crocker was one of the founders and chief technology officer of [[CyberCash]], Inc. He has also been an [[IETF]] security area director, a member of the [[Internet Architecture Board]], chair of the [[Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers]] (ICANN) Security and Stability Advisory Committee, a board member of the [[Internet Society]] and numerous other Internet-related volunteer positions. Crocker is chair of the board of ICANN.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icann.org/en/announcements/announcement-1-24jun11-en.htm|title=ICANN news release|date=June 2011}}</ref>
For this work, Crocker was awarded the 2002 [[IEEE]] [[IEEE Internet Award|Internet Award]] "for leadership in creation of key elements in open evolution of Internet protocols". In 2012, Crocker was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
[[Image:Jon Postel.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Jon Postel, c. 1994]]
===Jon Postel=== {{main|Jon Postel}} '''Jon Postel''' (1943–1998) was a researcher at the [[Information Sciences Institute]]. He was editor of all early Internet standards specifications, such as the [[Request for Comments]] (RFC) series. His beard and sandals made him "the most recognizable archetype of an Internet pioneer".<ref>{{cite web |title= A ten year tribute to Jon Postel: An Internet visionary, 1943-1998 |date= October 16, 2008 |publisher= Internet Society |url= http://www.isoc.org/awards/postel/memory.shtml |accessdate= March 30, 2011 }}</ref>
The [[Internet Society]]'s [[Postel Award]] is named in his honor, as is the Postel Center at [[Information Sciences Institute]]. His obituary was written by [[Vint Cerf]] and published as RFC 2468 in remembrance of Postel and his work. In 2012, Postel was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Joyce K. Reynolds=== {{main|Joyce K. Reynolds}} '''Joyce K. Reynolds''' (died 2015) was an American [[computer scientist]] and served as part of the editorial team of the [[Request For Comments]] series from 1987 to 2006. She performed the [[Internet Assigned Numbers Authority|IANA]] function with [[Jon Postel]] until this was transferred to [[ICANN]], then worked with ICANN in this role until 2001, while remaining an employee of [[Information Sciences Institute|ISI]].<ref name=ih>{{cite web|url=http://www.postel.org/pipermail/internet-history/2003-October/000343.html|title=Internet History Project biography, 2003|accessdate=26 July 2009}}</ref>
As Area Director of the User Services area, she was a member of the [[IESG|Internet Engineering Steering Group]] of the [[IETF]] from 1990 to March 1998.<ref>[http://www.ietf.org/iesg/past-members.html "Past IESG Members and IETF Chairs"], Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF), retrieved 5 March 2013</ref>
Together with [[Bob Braden]], she received the 2006 [[Postel Award]] in recognition of her services to the Internet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isoc.org/isoc/media/releases/061110pr.shtml|title=Bob Braden and Joyce K. Reynolds recognized with the Internet Society's Postel Award|date=10 November 2006|accessdate=30 July 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111213052355/http://www.isoc.org/isoc/media/releases/061110pr.shtml|archivedate=13 December 2011|df=}}</ref> She is mentioned, along with a brief biography, in RFC 1336, ''Who's Who in the Internet'' (1992).<ref name=RFC1336>RFC 1336 ''Who's Who in the Internet: Biographies of IAB, IESG and IRSG Members'', G. Malkin, Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF), May 1992</ref>
===Danny Cohen=== {{Main |Danny Cohen (engineer)}} '''Danny Cohen''' led several projects on real-time interactive applications over the [[ARPANet]] and the [[Internet]] starting in 1973.<ref>[http://www.internethalloffame.org/inductees/danny-cohen "Danny Cohen biography"], Internet Hall of Fame, Internet Society, accessed 14 July 2012</ref> After serving on the computer science faculty at [[Harvard University]] (1969–1973) and [[California Institute of Technology|Caltech]] (1976), he joined the [[Information Sciences Institute]] (ISI) at [[University of Southern California]] (USC). At ISI (1973–1993) he started many network related projects including, one to allow interactive, real-time speech over the [[ARPANet]], packet-voice, packet-video, and Internet Concepts.<ref>"RFC 0741: Specifications for the Network Voice Protocol (NVP)", Nov-22-1977.</ref> In 1981 he adapted his visual flight simulator to run over the [[ARPANet]], the first application of packet switching networks to real-time applications. In 1993, he worked on [[Distributed Interactive Simulation]] through several projects funded by [[United States Department of Defense]]. He is probably best known for his 1980 paper "On Holy Wars and a Plea for Peace"<ref name="HOLY">{{cite IETF | title = On Holy Wars and a Plea for Peace | ien = 137 | last1 = Cohen | first1 = Danny | date = 1 April 1980 | quote = ...which bit should travel first, the bit from the little end of the word, or the bit from the big end of the word? The followers of the former approach are called the Little-Endians, and the followers of the latter are called the Big-Endians. | publisher = [[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]] }} Also published at ''[[IEEE Computer]]'', [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=1667115 October 1981 issue].</ref> which adopted the terminology of [[endianness]] for computing.
Cohen was elected to the [[National Academy of Engineering]] in 2006 for contributions to the advanced design, graphics, and real-time network protocols of computer systems<ref name="NAE">[http://www.nae.edu/nae/naepub.nsf/Members+By+UNID/4424CB034570705786257552006B36FC?opendocument National Academy of Engineering member] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528040346/http://www.nae.edu/nae/naepub.nsf/Members+By+UNID/4424CB034570705786257552006B36FC?opendocument |date=2010-05-28 }}, 2006</ref> and as an [[IEEE Fellow]] in 2010 for contributions to protocols for packet switching in real-time applications.<ref name="IEEE">[http://www.ieee.org/membership_services/membership/fellows/chronology/fellows_2010.html IEEE Fellow] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516075924/http://www.ieee.org/membership_services/membership/fellows/chronology/fellows_2010.html |date=2013-05-16 }}, 2010</ref> In 1993 he received a [[United States Air Force]] [[Meritorious Civilian Service Award]]. And in 2012, Cohen was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Paul Mockapetris=== {{main|Paul Mockapetris}} '''Paul V. Mockapetris''' (born 1948), while working with [[Jon Postel]] at the [[Information Sciences Institute]] (ISI) in 1983, proposed the [[Domain Name System]] (DNS) architecture.<ref>RFC 882 - Domain Names - Concepts and Facilities, November 1983</ref><ref>RFC 883 - Domain Names - Implementation and Specification, November 1983</ref> He was [[IETF]] chair from 1994 to 1996.<ref>[http://www.nominum.com/who-we-are/board-of-directors/paul-mockapetris Biography of Paul Mockapetris] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830190817/http://www.nominum.com/who-we-are/board-of-directors/paul-mockapetris |date=2010-08-30 }}, Nominum web site</ref>
Mockapetris received the 1997 [[John C. Dvorak]] Telecommunications Excellence Award "Personal Achievement - Network Engineering" for DNS design and implementation, the 2003 [[IEEE Internet Award]] for his contributions to DNS, and the Distinguished Alumnus award from the [[University of California, Irvine]]. In May 2005, he received the ACM [[SIGCOMM Award|Sigcomm lifetime award]]. In 2012, Mockapetris was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===David Clark=== {| cellpadding="1" style="width: 220px; float: right; clear: right; border: 1px solid #8888aa; background: #f7f8ff; padding: 5px; margin: 0 0 15px 15px; text-align: left;" |<small>'''We reject: kings, presidents and voting.<br />We believe in: rough consensus and running code.''<br>    -Dave Clark at IETF 24''''' <ref name=ClarkQuote>{{cite web | url = http://ietf.org/proceedings/prior29/IETF24.pdf | title = A Cloudy Crystal Ball -- Visions of the Future | page = 551 | format = [[w:Portable Document Format|PDF]] | date = 1992-07-16 | accessdate = 2011-03-05 }} (Presentation given at the 24th [[Internet Engineering Task Force]].)</ref></small> |} {{main|David D. Clark}} '''David D. Clark''' (born 1944) is an [[United States|American]] [[computer scientist]].<ref>[http://www.csail.mit.edu/user/1526 David Clark's Biography], MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory</ref> During the period of tremendous growth and expansion of the Internet from 1981 to 1989, he acted as chief protocol architect in the development of the Internet, and chaired the Internet Activities Board, which later became the [[Internet Architecture Board]]. He is currently a senior research scientist at the [[MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory]].
In 1990 Clark was awarded the ACM [[SIGCOMM Award]] "in recognition of his major contributions to Internet protocol and architecture."<ref>[http://www.sigcomm.org/awards/sigcomm-awards "SIGCOMM Award Recipients"], ACM, retrieved 5 March 2013</ref> In 1998 he received the [[IEEE Richard W. Hamming Medal]] "for leadership and major contributions to the architecture of the Internet as a universal information medium".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ieee.org/documents/hamming_rl.pdf |title=IEEE Richard W. Hamming Medal Recipients |publisher=[[IEEE]] |accessdate=May 29, 2011}}</ref> In 2001 he was inducted as a Fellow of the [[Association for Computing Machinery]] for "his preeminent role in the development of computer communication and the Internet, including architecture, protocols, security, and telecommunications policy".<ref>[http://fellows.acm.org/fellow_citation.cfm?id=1239037&srt=all "ACM Fellow Citation for David D. Clark"], ACM, 2001, retrieved 5 March 2013</ref> In 2001, he was awarded the Telluride Tech Festival Award of Technology in Telluride, Colorado,<ref>[http://www.techfestival.org/past-honorees/ "Telluride Tech Festival Award of Technology: Past Honorees"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111017185018/http://www.techfestival.org/past-honorees/ |date=2011-10-17 }}, Telluride Technology Festival, 2001, retrieved 5 March 2013</ref> and in 2011 the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Oxford Internet Institute, University of Oxford "in recognition of his intellectual and institutional contributions to the advance of the Internet."<ref>[http://www.oii.ox.ac.uk/news/?id=564 "Computer Scientist David Clark Receives Lifetime Achievement Award from the Oxford Internet Institute"], Oxford Internet Institute, University of Oxford, 22 July 2011</ref>
===Susan Estrada=== {{main|Susan Estrada}} '''Susan Estrada''' founded [[CERFnet]], one of the original regional IP networks, in 1988. Through her leadership and collaboration with [[PSINet]] and [[UUnet]], Estrada helped form the interconnection enabling the first commercial Internet traffic via the Commercial Internet Exchange.<ref name="inducted">{{cite news |title= INTERNET HALL of FAME PIONEER Susan Estrada |url=http://www.hpcwire.com/off-the-wire/susan-estrada-inducted-internet-hall-fame/ |date=8 April 2014}}</ref><ref name="internethalloffame">{{cite news |title=Susan Estrada Inducted into Internet Hall of Fame |url=http://internethalloffame.org/inductees/susan-estrada 2014}}</ref> She wrote ''Connecting to the Internet'' in 1993 and she was inducted to the Internet Hall of Fame in 2014. She is on the Board of Trustees of the [[Internet Society]].
===Dave Mills=== {{main|David L. Mills}} [[Image:Ntp logo.jpeg|right|150px|[[Network Time Protocol]] Public Services Project logo<ref>[http://support.ntp.org/ Network Time Protocol Public Services Project logo], NTPPSP web site</ref>]] '''David L. Mills''' (born 1938) is an [[United States|American]] [[computer engineering|computer engineer]].<ref>[http://www.eecis.udel.edu/~mills/bio.html "David L. Mills Biography and Credentials"], University of Delaware</ref> Mills earned his [[PhD]] in Computer and Communication Sciences from the [[University of Michigan]] in 1971. While at Michigan he worked on the [[DARPA|ARPA]] sponsored Conversational Use of Computers (CONCOMP) project and developed [[PDP-8|DEC PDP-8]] based hardware and software to allow terminals to be connected over phone lines to an [[IBM System/360]] [[mainframe computer]].<ref>[http://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/handle/2027.42/6635 ''The Data Concentrator''], David Mills, May 1968, CONCOMP Project, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor</ref><ref>[http://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/handle/2027.42/6642 ''System/360 interface engineering report''], D. L. Mills, November 1967, CONCOMP Project, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor</ref>
Mills was the chairman of the [[GADS Task Force|Gateway Algorithms and Data Structures Task Force]] (GADS) and the first chairman of the Internet Architecture Task Force.<ref name=Quarterman>{{cite book|title=Matrix: Computer Networks and Conferencing Systems Worldwide|author=John S. Quarterman|edition=2|publisher=Digital Press|year=1990|url=http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=77526|isbn=1-55558-033-5|pages=185–186}}</ref> He invented the [[Network Time Protocol]] (1981),<ref>[http://tools.ietf.org/pdf/rfc778 RFC 778: ''DCNET Internet Clock Service''], D.L. Mills, COMSAT Laboratories, April 18, 1981</ref><ref>[http://tools.ietf.org/pdf/rfc958 RFC 958: ''Network Time Protocol (NTP)''], D.L. Mills, M/A-COM Linkabit, September 1985</ref> the [[LSI-11|DEC LSI-11]] based [[fuzzball router]] that was used for the 56 kbit/s [[NSFNET]] (1985),<ref>[http://nsf.gov/about/history/nsf0050/internet/fuzzball.htm "Fuzzball: The Innovative Router"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520060410/http://nsf.gov/about/history/nsf0050/internet/fuzzball.htm |date=2011-05-20 }}, web page on NSF's [http://nsf.gov/about/history/nsf0050/internet/internet.htm "The Internet: Changing the Way We Communicate"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514043622/http://www.nsf.gov/about/history/nsf0050/internet/internet.htm |date=2011-05-14 }}</ref> the [[Exterior Gateway Protocol]] (1984),<ref>[http://tools.ietf.org/pdf/rfc904 RFC 904: ''Exterior Gateway Protocol Formal Specification''], D.L. Mills, April 1984</ref> and inspired the author of [[Ping (networking utility)|ping]] (1983).<ref>[http://ftp.arl.army.mil/~mike/ping.html "The Story of the PING Program"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514103713/http://ftp.arl.army.mil/~mike/ping.html |date=2011-05-14 }}, Mike Muuss</ref> He is an emeritus professor at the [[University of Delaware]].
In 1999 he was inducted as a [[Fellow]] of the [[Association for Computing Machinery]], and in 2002, as a Fellow of the [[Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers]] (IEEE). In 2008, Mills was elected to the [[National Academy of Engineering]] (NAE). In 2013 he received the [[IEEE Internet Award]] "For significant leadership and sustained contributions in the research, development, standardization, and deployment of quality time synchronization capabilities for the Internet."<ref>[http://www.ieee.org/about/awards/bios/internet_recipients.html#sect1 "IEEE Internet Award Recipients: 2013 - David Mills"], IEEE Web site, accessed 27 January 2013</ref>
===Radia Perlman=== [[File:Radia Perlman 2009.jpg |thumb|150px | Radia Perlman]] {{main|Radia Perlman}} '''Radia Joy Perlman''' (born 1951) is the software designer and network engineer who developed the [[spanning-tree protocol]] which is fundamental to the operation of [[network bridge]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mother of the Internet Radia Perlman speaks out|author=Bob Brown|publisher=[[Network World]]|date=May 5, 2006|url=http://www.networkworld.com/community/node/5738|accessdate=22 January 2010}}</ref> She also played an important role in the development of [[link-state routing protocols]] such as [[IS-IS]] (which had a significant influence on [[OSPF]]).<ref>[http://web.mit.edu/invent/iow/perlman.html "Inventor of the Week: Radia Perlman"], August 2007, Inventor Archive, Lemelson-MIT Program</ref> In 2010 she received the [[SIGCOMM Award|ACM SIGCOMM Award]] "for her fundamental contributions to the Internet routing and bridging protocols that we all use and take for granted every day."<ref>[http://www.sigcomm.org/awards/sigcomm-awards 2010 SIGCOMM Lifetime Achievement Award given to Radia Perlman], "for her fundamental contributions to the Internet routing and bridging protocols that we all use and take for granted every day", ACM SIGCOMM award recipients web page</ref>
===Dennis M. Jennings=== {{main|Dennis M. Jennings}} '''Dennis M. Jennings''' is an Irish physicist, academic, Internet pioneer, and venture capitalist. In 1984, the [[National Science Foundation]] (NSF) began construction of several regional [[supercomputing]] centers to provide very high-speed computing resources for the US research community. In 1985 NSF hired Jennings to lead the establishment of the [[National Science Foundation Network]] (NSFNET) to link five of the super-computing centers to enable sharing of resources and information. Jennings made three critical decisions that shaped the subsequent development of NSFNET:<ref>[http://www.livinginternet.com/i/ii_nsfnet.htm "Internet > History > NSFNET -- National Science Foundation Network"], ''livinginternet.com: The World's First Web Published Book'', 2000, accessed 16 July 2012</ref> * that it would be a general-purpose research network, not limited to connection of the supercomputers; * it would act as the backbone for connection of regional networks at each supercomputing site; and * it would use the [[ARPANET]]'s [[Internet protocol suite|TCP/IP protocols]].
Jennings was also actively involved in the start-up of research networks in Europe ([[European Academic Research Network]], EARN - President; [[EBONE]] - Board member) and Ireland ([[HEAnet]] - initial proposal and later Board member). He chaired the Board and General Assembly of the [[Council of European National Top Level Domain Registries]] (CENTR) from 1999 to early 2001 and was actively involved in the start-up of the [[Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers]] (ICANN). He was a member of the ICANN Board from 2007 to 2010, serving as Vice-Chair in 2009-2010.<ref name=RealNetPioneer>[http://www.independent.ie/business/technology/irelandrsquos-real-net-pioneer-1115628.html "Ireland's real net pioneer"], ''Independent.ie'', 4 October 2007</ref> In April 2014 Jennings was inducted into the Internet Hall of Fame.<ref>[http://www.internethalloffame.org/inductees/dennis-jennings "Dennis Jennings Internet Hall of Fame Pioneer"], Internet Hall of Fame, April 2014. Retrieved 27 June 2014.</ref>
===Steve Wolff=== [[File:Nsfnet logo.jpg|right|thumb|150px|[[NSFNET]] logo, c. 1987]] {{main|Stephen Wolff}} '''Stephen "Steve" Wolff''' participated in the development of [[ARPANET]] while working for the U.S. Army.<ref name=Wolff1>[http://newsroom.cisco.com/dlls/ts_073002.html "Stephen Wolff–Hustling for Innovation"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110120225414/http://newsroom.cisco.com/dlls/ts_073002.html |date=2011-01-20 }}, Charles Waltner, ''News@Cisco'', July 30, 2002</ref> In 1986 he became Division Director for Networking and Communications Research and Infrastructure at the [[National Science Foundation]] (NSF) where he managed the development of [[NSFNET]].<ref>[http://www.apress.com/book/view/9781430208693 ''On the Way to the Web: The Secret History of the Internet and Its Founders''], Michael A. Banks, Apress, New York, 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-4302-0869-3}}</ref> He also conceived the Gigabit Testbed, a joint NSF-[[DARPA]] project to prove the feasibility of IP networking at [[Gigabit per second#Gigabit per second|gigabit speeds]].<ref>[http://www.cnri.reston.va.us/gigafr/ "The Gigabit Testbed Initiative–Final Report"], Corporation for National Research Initiatives (CNRI), December 1996</ref> His work at NSF transformed the fledgling internet from a narrowly focused U.S. government project into the modern [[Internet]] with scholarly and commercial interest for the entire world.<ref>[http://www.isoc.org/internet/history/brief.shtml "A Brief History of the Internet"], Barry M. Leiner, et al., Internet Society, December 2003</ref> In 1994 he left NSF to join [[Cisco]] as a technical manager in Corporate Consulting Engineering.<ref name=Wolff1/> In 2011 he became the CTO at [[Internet2]].<ref>[http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20110401/FREE/110409996# "Internet2’s new chief technology officer helped create Internet No. 1"], Tom Henderson, ''Crain's Detroit Business'', April 1, 2011</ref>
In 2002 the [[Internet Society]] recognized Wolff with its [[Postel Award]]. When presenting the award, Internet Society (ISOC) President and CEO Lynn St.Amour said “…Steve helped transform the Internet from an activity that served the specific goals of the research community to a worldwide enterprise which has energized scholarship and commerce throughout the world.”<ref name=PostelAward-2002>[http://www.internetsociety.org/stephen-wolff-receives-internet-societys-postel-service-award-2002 "Stephen Wolff Receives the Internet Society's Postel Service Award for 2002"], Internet Society, 24 June 2002</ref> The Internet Society also recognized Wolff in 1994 for his courage and leadership in advancing the Internet.<ref name=PostelAward-2002/>
===Sally Floyd=== {{main|Sally Floyd}} '''Sally Floyd''' is an [[United States|American]] engineer recognized for her extensive contributions to Internet architecture and her work in identifying practical ways to control and stabilize [[network congestion|Internet congestion]].<ref name="icsi2007">[http://www.icsi.berkeley.edu/icsi/gazette/2007/09/sally-floyd-sigcomm-award "Sally Floyd Wins 2007 SIGCOMM Award"], ICSI, Sept. 2007 (last visited Oct. 7, 2012).</ref> She invented the [[random early detection]] active queue management scheme, which has been implemented in nearly all commercially available [[Router (computing)|routers]], and devised the now-common method of adding [[delay jitter]] to message timers to avoid synchronization collisions.<ref name="ieeeghn">IEEE, [http://www.ieeeghn.org/wiki/index.php/Sally_Floyd "Sally Floyd"], IEEE Global History Network (last visited Oct. 7, 2012).</ref> Floyd, with [[Vern Paxson]], in 1997 identified the lack of knowledge of [[network topology]] as the major obstacle in understanding how the Internet works.<ref>Albert-laszlo Barabasi and Jennifer Frangos, ''Linked: The New Science of Networks'' (Basic Books, 2002), p.150.</ref> This paper, "Why We Don't Know How to Simulate the Internet", was re-published as "Difficulties in Simulating the Internet" in 2001 and won the IEEE Communication Society's William R. Bennett Prize Paper Award.
Floyd is also a co-author on the standard for TCP [[Selective acknowledgement]] (SACK), [[Explicit Congestion Notification]] (ECN), the [[Datagram Congestion Control Protocol]] (DCCP) and [[TCP Friendly Rate Control]] (TFRC).
She received the [[IEEE Internet Award]] in 2005 and the ACM [[SIGCOMM Award]] in 2007 for her contributions to congestion control.<ref name="icsi2007" /> She has been involved in the [[Internet Advisory Board]], and is one of the top-ten most cited researchers in computer science.<ref name="icsi2007" />
===Van Jacobson=== [[File:Van Jacobson1.jpg |thumb|150px |Van Jacobson in January 2006]] {{main|Van Jacobson}} '''Van Jacobson''' is an [[United States|American]] [[computer scientist]], best known for his work on [[TCP/IP]] network performance and scaling.<ref name="SIGCOM-2001"/> His work redesigning [[TCP/IP]]'s flow control algorithms ([[TCP congestion avoidance algorithm|Jacobson's algorithm]])<ref>[http://ee.lbl.gov/papers/congavoid.pdf "Congestion avoidance and control"], Van Jacobson, ''Proceedings of SIGCOMM ’88'', Stanford, CA, Aug. 1988, ACM</ref><ref>[http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?doid=205447.205462 "Congestion avoidance and control"], Van Jacobson, ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review - Special twenty-fifth anniversary issue, Highlights from 25 years of the Computer Communication Review, Volume 25 Issue 1, Jan. 1995, pp.157-187</ref> to better handle congestion is said to have saved the Internet from collapsing in the late 1980s and early 1990s.<ref name="IEEE-2002"/> He is also known for the TCP/IP Header Compression protocol described in RFC 1144: ''Compressing TCP/IP Headers for Low-Speed Serial Links'', popularly known as [[Van Jacobson TCP/IP Header Compression]]. He is co-author of several widely used network diagnostic tools, including [[traceroute]], [[tcpdump]], and pathchar. He was a leader in the development of the [[Mbone|multicast backbone]] (MBone) and the multimedia tools vic,<ref>[http://ee.lbl.gov/vic/ "vic - Video Conferencing Tool"], web page at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory</ref> vat,<ref>[http://ee.lbl.gov/vat/ "vat - LBL Audio Conferencing Tool"], web page at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory</ref> and wb.<ref>[http://ee.lbl.gov/wb/ "wb - LBNL Whiteboard Tool"], web page at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory</ref>
For his work, Jacobson received the 2001 [[Association for Computing Machinery|ACM]] [[SIGCOMM Award|SIGCOMM Award for Lifetime Achievement]],<ref name=SIGCOM-2001>[http://www.sigcomm.org/awards/sigcomm-awards 2001 SIGCOMM Award for Lifetime Achievement] to Van Jacobson "for contributions to protocol architecture and congestion control."</ref> the 2003 [[IEEE]] [[Koji Kobayashi Computers and Communications Award]],<ref name=IEEE-2002>[http://www.ieee.org/about/awards/bios/kobayashi_recipients.html#sect10 "Van Jacobson: 2002 IEEE Koji Kobayashi Computers and Communications Award Recipient"], IEEE web site</ref> and was elected to the [[National Academy of Engineering]] in 2006.<ref>[http://www.nae.edu/MembersSection/Directory20412/30818.aspx "Mr. Van Jacobson"], Members Directory, National Academy of Engineering</ref> In 2012, Jacobson was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Ted Nelson=== [[File:Ted Nelson cropped.jpg |thumb|150px |Ted Nelson]] {{main|Ted Nelson}} '''Theodor Holm "Ted" Nelson''' (born 1937) is an [[United States|American]] [[sociologist]] and [[philosopher]]. In 1960 he founded [[Project Xanadu]] with the goal of creating a computer network with a simple user interface. Project Xanadu was to be a worldwide [[electronic publishing]] system using [[hypertext]] linking that would have created a universal library.<ref>[http://www.ibiblio.org/pioneers/nelson.html "Internet Pioneers: Ted Nelson"], web page at [http://ibiblio.org ibiblio.org], a collaboration of the School of Information and Library Science and the School of Journalism and Mass Communication at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.</ref> In 1963 he coined the terms "[[hypertext]]" and "[[hypermedia]]". In 1974 he wrote and published two books in one, [[Computer Lib|Computer Lib/Dream Machines]],<ref>[http://www.arch.kth.se/unrealstockholm/unreal_web/seminar03_2006/computerlib.pdf ''Computer Lib (You can and must understand computers NOW) / Dream Machines (Come Dream along with me: The Best Is Yet To Be)''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214170131/http://www.arch.kth.se/unrealstockholm/unreal_web/seminar03_2006/computerlib.pdf |date=2010-12-14 }}, Theodor H. Nelson, self-published, 1974, {{ISBN|978-0-89347-002-9}}</ref> that has been hailed as "the most important book in the history of new media."<ref>[http://www.newmediareader.com/book_samples/nmr-21-nelson.pdf "Chapter 21: From Computer Lib / Dream Machines, Theodor H. Nelson, 1970-1974"], ''The New Media Reader'', Noah Wardrip-Fruin and Nick Montfort (Eds), MIT Press, February 2003, 837 pp., {{ISBN|978-0-262-23227-2}}</ref> Sadly, his grand ideas from the 1960s and 1970s never became completed projects.
===Tim Berners-Lee=== [[File:WWW logo by Robert Cailliau.svg|right|thumb|150px|The Web's historic logo designed by [[Robert Cailliau]].]] {{main|Tim Berners-Lee}} '''Timothy John "Tim" Berners-Lee''' (born 1955) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[physicist]] and [[computer scientist]].<ref name="W3Bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.w3.org/People/Berners-Lee/Longer.html|title=Berners-Lee Longer Biography|publisher=World Wide Web Consortium|accessdate=18 January 2011}}</ref> In 1980, while working at [[CERN]], he proposed a project using [[hypertext]] to facilitate sharing and updating information among researchers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Berners-Lee's original proposal to CERN|publisher=World Wide Web Consortium|date=March 1989|url=http://www.w3.org/History/1989/proposal.html|accessdate=25 May 2008}}</ref> While there, he built a prototype system named [[ENQUIRE]].<ref name="linvinginternet">{{cite web|last=Stewart|first=Bill|title=Tim Berners-Lee, Robert Cailliau, and the World Wide Web|url=http://www.livinginternet.com/w/wi_lee.htm|accessdate=22 July 2010}}</ref> Back at CERN in 1989 he conceived of and, in 1990, together with [[Robert Cailliau]], created the first client and server implementations for what became the [[World Wide Web]]. Berners-Lee is the director of the [[World Wide Web Consortium]] (W3C), a standards organization which oversees and encourages the Web's continued development, co-Director of the [[Web Science Trust]], and founder of the [[World Wide Web Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Tim Berners-Lee receives Draper Prize|url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2007/draper-prize.html|publisher=MIT News, [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]|accessdate= May 25, 2008}}</ref>
In 1994, Berners-Lee became one of only six members of the [[World Wide Web Hall of Fame]].<ref name="The World-Wide Web Hall of Fame">{{cite web|title=The World-Wide Web Hall of Fame|url=http://botw.org/1994/awards/fame.html |publisher=[[Best of the Web Directory]]}}</ref> In 2004, Berners-Lee was [[Order of the British Empire|knighted]] by Queen [[Elizabeth II]] for his pioneering work.<ref name=tecb>{{cite news | title =Web's inventor gets a knighthood |publisher=BBC |date=31 December 2003 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/3357073.stm | accessdate=25 May 2008 }}</ref> In April 2009, he was elected a foreign associate of the [[United States National Academy of Sciences]], based in Washington, D.C.<ref>{{cite web|title=Timothy Berners-Lee Elected to National Academy of Sciences|url=http://www.ddj.com/217200450|publisher=[[Dr. Dobb's Journal]]|accessdate=9 June 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|accessdate=17 January 2011|date=28 April 2009|title=72 New Members Chosen By Academy|publisher=United States National Academy of Sciences|url=http://www8.nationalacademies.org/onpinews/newsitem.aspx?RecordID=04282009}}</ref> In 2012, Berners-Lee was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Robert Cailliau=== [[File:Robert Cailliau On Desk.jpg |thumb|150px |Robert Cailliau]] {{main|Robert Cailliau}} '''Robert Cailliau''' ({{IPA-fr|kaˈjo|lang}}, born 1947), is a [[Belgian]] [[Informatics (academic field)|informatics engineer]] and [[Computer science|computer scientist]] who, working with [[Tim Berners-Lee]] and [[Nicola Pellow]] at [[CERN]], [[Software developer|developed]] the [[World Wide Web]].<ref name="Berners-Lee"/> In 2012 he was inducted into the [[Internet Hall of Fame]] by the [[Internet Society]].<ref name="IHOF-2012"/>
===Nicola Pellow=== {{main|Nicola Pellow}} [[File:NPellow.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Nicola Pellow and Tim Berners-Lee in their office at CERN.]] '''Nicola Pellow''', one of the nineteen member of the ''WWW Project'' at [[CERN]] working with [[Tim Berners-Lee]], is recognized for developing the first cross-platform internet browser, [[Line Mode Browser]], that displayed web-pages on dumb terminals and was released in May 1991.<ref name="CERN10">{{cite web|title=Ten Years Public Domain for the Original Web Software|url=http://tenyears-www.web.cern.ch/tenyears-www/Story/WelcomeStory.html|publisher=CERN|accessdate=21 July 2010}}</ref> She joined the project in November 1990, while an undergraduate math student enrolled in a [[sandwich course]] at Leicester Polytechnic (now [[De Montfort University]]).<ref name="CERN10" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=How the Web was Born: The Story of the World Wide Web|last=Gillies, James; Cailliau, R.|first=|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2000|isbn=0192862073|location=|pages=6}}</ref> She left CERN at the end of August 1991, but returned after graduating in 1992, and worked with [[Robert Cailliau]] on [[MacWWW]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.internet-guide.co.uk/MacWWW.html|title=MacWWW: the first web browser for the Apple Macintosh platform|website=www.internet-guide.co.uk|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref><ref>[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/7/77/MacWWWscreenshot.gif Screenshot of the first Mac web browser]</ref> the first web browser for the [[classic Mac OS]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Bill|last=Stewart|title=Web Browser History|url=http://www.livinginternet.com/w/wi_browse.htm|publisher=Living Internet |date=2015 |accessdate=21 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="Berners-Lee">{{cite web|last=Berners-Lee|first=Tim|title=Macintosh Browser|date=3 November 1992|url=http://www.w3.org/History/19921103-hypertext/hypertext/WWW/Macintosh/Status.html|publisher=[[World Wide Web Consortium]]|accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref>
===Mark P. McCahill=== {{main|Mark P. McCahill}}
'''Mark P. McCahill''' (born 1956) is an American programmer and systems architect. While working at the [[University of Minnesota]] he led the development of the [[Gopher (protocol)|Gopher]] protocol (1991), the effective predecessor of the [[World Wide Web]], and contributed to the development and popularization of a number of other Internet technologies from the 1980s.<ref>[http://www.opencobalt.org/community/contributors-volunteers/mark-mccahill-collaborative-systems-architect "Mark McCahill, Collaborative Systems Architect"], Biographical sketch, Open Cobalt. Retrieved 24 July 2013.</ref><ref>[http://searchenginewatch.com/article/2067063/A-Pre-Web-Search-Engine-Gopher-Turns-Ten "A Pre-Web Search Engine, Gopher Turns Ten"], Chris Sherman, Search Engine Watch, 5 February 2002.</ref><ref>[http://www.jucs.org/jucs_1_4/evolution_of_internet_gopher "Evolution of Internet Gopher"], Mark P. McCahill and Farhad X. Anklesaria, ''Journal of Universal Computer Science'', vol 1, issue 4 (April 1995), pages 235-246.</ref>
===Marc Andreessen=== [[File:Marc Andreessen.jpg |thumb|150px |Mark Andreessen]] {{main|Marc Andreessen}} '''Marc L. Andreessen''' (born 1971) is an [[United States|American]] [[software engineer]], [[entrepreneur]], and [[investor]]. Working with [[Eric Bina]] while at [[National Center for Supercomputing Applications|NCSA]], he co-authored [[Mosaic (web browser)|Mosaic]], the first widely used [[web browser]]. He is also co-founder of [[Netscape Communications Corporation]].<ref name="co-founder">{{cite web|url=http://www.alleyinsider.com/2008/6/marc-andreessen-joins-facebook-board |title=Marc Andreessen Joins Facebook Board |publisher=Alleyinsider.com |author=Dan Frommer |date= |accessdate=2008-10-05}}</ref>
===Eric Bina=== {{main|Eric Bina}} '''Eric J. Bina''' (born 1964) is an [[United States|American]] [[computer programmer]]. In 1993, together with [[Marc Andreessen]], he authored the first version of [[Mosaic (web browser)|Mosaic]] while working at [[National Center for Supercomputing Applications|NCSA]] at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]].<ref name="The World-Wide Web Hall of Fame"/> Mosaic is famed as the first [[killer application]] that popularized the Internet. He is also a co-founder of [[Netscape Communications Corporation]].<ref>[http://www.ncsa.illinois.edu/Projects/mosaic.html "About NCSA Mosaic"] {{webarchive|url=http://wayback.vefsafn.is/wayback/20160605115205/http://www.ncsa.illinois.edu/Projects/mosaic.html |date=2016-06-05 }}, NCSA web site, University of Illinois</ref>
==Birth of the Internet plaque== A plaque commemorating the "Birth of the Internet" was dedicated at a conference on the history and future of the internet on July 28, 2005 and is displayed at the [[Gates Computer Science Building, Stanford|Gates Computer Science Building]], Stanford University.<ref>{{cite news |title= Cyber-pioneer Vint Cerf to headline July 28 forum on the future of Internet |work= Press release |publisher= Stanford Report |date= July 13, 2005 |author= David Orenstein |url= http://news.stanford.edu/news/2005/july13/forum-071305.html |accessdate= April 7, 2011 }}</ref> The text printed and embossed in black into the brushed bronze surface of the plaque reads:<ref>[http://mercury.lcs.mit.edu/~jnc/plaque.html "Stanford University 'Birth of the Internet' Plaque"], web page, J. Noel Chiappa, Laboratory for Computer Science, MIT</ref>
<center> '''BIRTH OF THE INTERNET''' <small> THE ARCHITECTURE OF THE INTERNET AND THE DESIGN OF THE CORE NETWORKING PROTOCOL TCP (WHICH LATER BECAME TCP/IP) WERE CONCEIVED BY VINTON G. CERF AND ROBERT E. KAHN DURING 1973 WHILE CERF WAS AT STANFORD'S DIGITAL SYSTEMS LABORATORY AND KAHN WAS AT ARPA (LATER DARPA). IN THE SUMMER OF 1976, CERF LEFT STANFORD TO MANAGE THE PROGRAM WITH KAHN AT ARPA.
THEIR WORK BECAME KNOWN IN SEPTEMBER 1973 AT A NETWORKING CONFERENCE IN ENGLAND. CERF AND KAHN'S SEMINAL PAPER WAS PUBLISHED IN MAY 1974.
CERF, YOGEN K. DALAL, AND CARL SUNSHINE WROTE THE FIRST FULL TCP SPECIFICATION IN DECEMBER 1974. WITH THE SUPPORT OF DARPA, EARLY IMPLEMENTATIONS OF TCP (AND IP LATER) WERE TESTED BY BOLT BERANEK AND NEWMAN (BBN), STANFORD, AND UNIVERSITY COLLEGE LONDON DURING 1975.
BBN BUILT THE FIRST INTERNET GATEWAY, NOW KNOWN AS A ROUTER, TO LINK NETWORKS TOGETHER. IN SUBSEQUENT YEARS, RESEARCHERS AT MIT AND USC-ISI, AMONG MANY OTHERS, PLAYED KEY ROLES IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE SET OF INTERNET PROTOCOLS.
'''KEY STANFORD RESEARCH ASSOCIATES AND FOREIGN VISITORS'''
VINTON CERF DAG BELSNES (Seal of LELAND STANFORD JAMES MATHIS RONALD CRANE JUNIOR UNIVERSITY BOB METCALFE YOGEN DALAL ★★★ 1891 ★★★ DARRYL RUBIN JUDITH ESTRIN motto in German: JOHN SHOCH RICHARD KARP DIE LUFT DER FREIHEIT WEHT) CARL SUNSHINE GERARD LE LANN KUNINOBU TANNO
'''DARPA''' ROBERT KAHN
'''COLLABORATING GROUPS'''
'''BOLT BERANEK AND NEWMAN''' WILLIAM PLUMMER • [[GINNY STRAZISAR]] • [[Ray_Tomlinson|RAY TOMLINSON]]
'''MIT''' [[Noel Chiappa|NOEL CHIAPPA]] • DAVID CLARK • STEPHEN KENT • DAVID P. REED
'''NDRE''' YNGVAR LUNDH • [[Pål Spilling|PAAL SPILLING]]
'''UNIVERSITY COLLEGE LONDON''' FRANK DEIGNAN • MARTINE GALLAND • PETER HIGGINSON ANDREW HINCHLEY • PETER KIRSTEIN • ADRIAN STOKES
'''USC-ISI''' ROBERT BRADEN • DANNY COHEN • DANIEL LYNCH • JON POSTEL
ULTIMATELY, THOUSANDS IF NOT TENS TO HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS HAVE CONTRIBUTED THEIR EXPERTISE TO THE EVOLUTION OF THE INTERNET.
DEDICATED JULY 28, 2005 </small></center>
